texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every Linux user experienced at least one "battle of the text editors" once in their lifetime. I even participated in a few! Text editors form the foundation of nearly every Linux user's workflow. You need to use one eventually, whether for quick configuration file edits, developing software, or writing blog posts in markdown  (like this one) !
texts.text: Every Linux user experienced at least one "battle of the text editors" once in their lifetime. I even participated in a few! Text editors form the foundation of nearly every Linux user's workflow. You need to use one eventually, whether for quick configuration file edits, developing software, or writing blog posts in markdown  (like this one) !

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: An older and much wiser Linux engineer told me this early in my career:
texts.text: An older and much wiser Linux engineer told me this early in my career:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Everyone spends time arguing about the best text editor. Nobody spends time being grateful that we have so many great choices!
texts.text: Everyone spends time arguing about the best text editor. Nobody spends time being grateful that we have so many great choices!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: He was totally right. Sometimes we quickly forget about the benefits of choice in open source software.
texts.text: He was totally right. Sometimes we quickly forget about the benefits of choice in open source software.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But before I could say anything else, he said:
texts.text: But before I could say anything else, he said:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: And, naturally, emacs is the best editor out there, anyway.
texts.text: And, naturally, emacs is the best editor out there, anyway.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Why migrate to vim?
texts.text: Why migrate to vim?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Visual Studio Code , or vscode, comes from Microsoft and delivers a full-featured editor and IDE with tons of plugins available. It also offers plenty of extensions that enable extra functions for certain file types and merges testing output into the same interface.
texts.text: Visual Studio Code , or vscode, comes from Microsoft and delivers a full-featured editor and IDE with tons of plugins available. It also offers plenty of extensions that enable extra functions for certain file types and merges testing output into the same interface.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, newer releases performed poorly on my machine. I spent too much time going through extensions to find out which one was causing the performance drops. Then I noticed that my extension usage had gone way overboard and I wasn't vetting new extensions as I should have.
texts.text: However, newer releases performed poorly on my machine. I spent too much time going through extensions to find out which one was causing the performance drops. Then I noticed that my extension usage had gone way overboard and I wasn't vetting new extensions as I should have.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Privacy questions  came up from time to time, too. Switching to something like  vscodium  helped with the privacy issues but the slowdowns from extensions came right back.
texts.text: Privacy questions  came up from time to time, too. Switching to something like  vscodium  helped with the privacy issues but the slowdowns from extensions came right back.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What really pushed me over the edge was  inconsistency .
texts.text: What really pushed me over the edge was  inconsistency .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Whenever I made edits of system configuration files, wrote comments in git commits, or made a quick change in a text document, I was in vim. I began packaging more software in Fedora and it was much quicker to open a spec file in vim, make commits, and test my changes. My vim configuration file grew as I changed settings to make edits easier and I loaded a few plugins (with  vim-plug ).
texts.text: Whenever I made edits of system configuration files, wrote comments in git commits, or made a quick change in a text document, I was in vim. I began packaging more software in Fedora and it was much quicker to open a spec file in vim, make commits, and test my changes. My vim configuration file grew as I changed settings to make edits easier and I loaded a few plugins (with  vim-plug ).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I found myself opening vscode less and less often. I was gradually improving my skills in vim with visual selections, copy/paste, and moving quickly through files  (oh how I love using curly braces to jump between ansible tasks) . Did I make mistakes? Oh, yes. And if anyone was watching over my shoulder, it would have been hilarious (for them).
texts.text: I found myself opening vscode less and less often. I was gradually improving my skills in vim with visual selections, copy/paste, and moving quickly through files  (oh how I love using curly braces to jump between ansible tasks) . Did I make mistakes? Oh, yes. And if anyone was watching over my shoulder, it would have been hilarious (for them).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: New adventures outside my comfort zone are always fun for me, so I embarked on a migration to vim as my full time editor.
texts.text: New adventures outside my comfort zone are always fun for me, so I embarked on a migration to vim as my full time editor.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Initial challenges
texts.text: Initial challenges

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Old habits die hard.
texts.text: Old habits die hard.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My muscle memory of running
texts.text: My muscle memory of running

texts.label: code
texts.orig: code -n .
texts.text: code -n .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: kept kicking in when I went to edit something, so I removed vscode from my system entirely. Just like throwing out the cookies as you start a diet, there's no going back now.
texts.text: kept kicking in when I went to edit something, so I removed vscode from my system entirely. Just like throwing out the cookies as you start a diet, there's no going back now.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: File manager
texts.text: File manager

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I struggled with replicating the file manager component of vscode that runs down the left side. My dependency on that file list was  deep . I stumbled upon a blog post called  Oil and vinegar - split windows and the project drawer  that argued against some of the file manager drawer designs.
texts.text: I struggled with replicating the file manager component of vscode that runs down the left side. My dependency on that file list was  deep . I stumbled upon a blog post called  Oil and vinegar - split windows and the project drawer  that argued against some of the file manager drawer designs.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A friend showed me  fzf  and the corrsponding vim plugin,  fzf.vim . At first, I was totally lost. Then I found a video from  samoshkin  that  explained how to use fzf  with the zsh shell as well as vim.
texts.text: A friend showed me  fzf  and the corrsponding vim plugin,  fzf.vim . At first, I was totally lost. Then I found a video from  samoshkin  that  explained how to use fzf  with the zsh shell as well as vim.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: {{< youtube qgG5Jhi_Els >}}
texts.text: {{< youtube qgG5Jhi_Els >}}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's now a critical part of my workflow in large projects. If I know the filename, I type
texts.text: It's now a critical part of my workflow in large projects. If I know the filename, I type

texts.label: code
texts.orig: :Files
texts.text: :Files

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , press enter, and search for the file. If I know what's in the file, I type
texts.text: , press enter, and search for the file. If I know what's in the file, I type

texts.label: code
texts.orig: :Ag
texts.text: :Ag

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , press enter, and type search strings to match files.
texts.text: , press enter, and type search strings to match files.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Spell checking
texts.text: Spell checking

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Vim makes it easy to write markdown, but I missed the spell checking in vscode. Luckily vim has built-in spell checking and a friend showed me how to set up a toggle that turns it on and off:
texts.text: Vim makes it easy to write markdown, but I missed the spell checking in vscode. Luckily vim has built-in spell checking and a friend showed me how to set up a toggle that turns it on and off:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: noremap <silent><leader>S :set spell!<CR>
texts.text: noremap <silent><leader>S :set spell!<CR>

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The default
texts.text: The default

texts.label: code
texts.orig: leader
texts.text: leader

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: key is the backslash, so I can hit backslash followed by a capital S to enable spell checking. Hitting the same keys (backslash, then capital S) turns the spell checking off. I leave spell checking off by default and enable it just before publishing when I do my proofreading. It reduces distractions while I'm writing.
texts.text: key is the backslash, so I can hit backslash followed by a capital S to enable spell checking. Hitting the same keys (backslash, then capital S) turns the spell checking off. I leave spell checking off by default and enable it just before publishing when I do my proofreading. It reduces distractions while I'm writing.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Colors
texts.text: Colors

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The  solarized-dark  theme has been my workhorse for years and it's easy on my eyes. I found some vim examples online and the author was using the  nord  theme. It's a blend of blues and light greys that gives me a little more contrast while still being easy on my eyes during the workday.
texts.text: The  solarized-dark  theme has been my workhorse for years and it's easy on my eyes. I found some vim examples online and the author was using the  nord  theme. It's a blend of blues and light greys that gives me a little more contrast while still being easy on my eyes during the workday.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I started with a few plugins:
texts.text: I started with a few plugins:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
call plug#begin()
Plug 'arcticicestudio/nord-vim'
Plug 'vim-airline/vim-airline'
Plug 'vim-airline/vim-airline-themes'
call plug#end()
texts.text:
call plug#begin()
Plug 'arcticicestudio/nord-vim'
Plug 'vim-airline/vim-airline'
Plug 'vim-airline/vim-airline-themes'
call plug#end()

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This adds support for the nord theme for all of vim as well as for  vim-airline  (an awesome vim status bar plugin). I enabled nord by default as well:
texts.text: This adds support for the nord theme for all of vim as well as for  vim-airline  (an awesome vim status bar plugin). I enabled nord by default as well:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
" Colors
colorscheme nord                               
highlight Comment ctermfg=darkgray cterm=italic
let g:airline_theme='nord'
texts.text:
" Colors
colorscheme nord                               
highlight Comment ctermfg=darkgray cterm=italic
let g:airline_theme='nord'

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The
texts.text: The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ctermfg-darkgray
texts.text: ctermfg-darkgray

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: helps improve contrast for some of the darkest colors and
texts.text: helps improve contrast for some of the darkest colors and

texts.label: code
texts.orig: cterm=italic
texts.text: cterm=italic

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: makes comments italicized.
texts.text: makes comments italicized.
